Holy Cross—Close Game Goes To Swarthmore.
Considering the calibre of teams which the nine has been forced
to face during the past ten days, the results achieved have been Very
creditable. But one contest displayed poor playing on the part of
Hopkins—the Princeton game. This was the first tilt of the schedule;
the players were for the most part stage-struck, and the twirlers were
unable to locate the plate. This is, in part, excusable when it is
considered that the wintry weather and the loss of the cage allowed
the team less than two weeks' practice in preparation for the opening
game.
Against Cornell, the 'Varsity fared better. Clever wielding of
the bat netted them. 13 tallies, and almost airtight fielding held the
big Red team within bounds. The single error of the game was made
by "Teddy" Welliver in the initial session. Seven free tickets also
helped Cornell to her 10 runs.
"Doc" Love was the hero of the Holy Cross game, as far as concerned the Homewood aggregation. He retired four batters by the
strike-out route, allowed eight 'Angles and issued not a single pass.
Horan, who served up the shoots for the visitors, displayed big league
stuff, allowing but one hit, which "Dick" Benson garnered on his first.
trip to the pate.
The start of the Swarthmore game raised the hopes of the Blfiek
and Blue ball tossers, but the Quakers came from behind in the
seventh and took the fruit of victory from the eager hands of the
local boys. Three errors on the part of Bloomsburg, and a dropped
fly by Knecht, were in a large measure responsible for this defeat.
The Boston College and Fordham games were cancelled ; the former on account of rain and the latter because of cold weather.

The Freshman Class has awakened! Why this burst of "pep"
is evidenced at this time the remainder of the University is at a
loss to know. Suffice it is to say
that the freshmen have seen fit to
mar the beauty of the campus
with gaudy flags and black and
green paint. Why should the rest
of the college demur? Have not
the freshmen proved sufficiently
to all concerned that they are the
kings of the campus, by defeating
the listless sophomores in every
activity this winter?
Let not the Class of '23 think,
however, because they have succeeded in annuling their regulations ten days before the time at
which they were due to be removed, that this gives them license to flaunt their numerals in
the face of all visitors to the University, as well as the rest of the
college.
This deplorable practice of enlivening the landscape with the

The Freshman Class has awakened! Why this burst of "pep"
is evidenced at this time the remainder of the University is at a
loss to know. Suffice it is to say
that the freshmen have seen fit to
mar the beauty of the campus
with gaudy flags and black and
green paint. Why should the rest
of the college demur? Have not
the freshmen proved sufficiently
to all concerned that they are the
kings of the campus, by defeating
the listless sophomores in every
activity this winter?
Let not the Class of '23 think,
however, because they have succeeded in annuling their regulations ten days before the time at
which they were due to be removed, that this gives them license to flaunt their numerals in
the face of all visitors to the University, as well as the rest of the
college.
This deplorable practice of enlivening the landscape with the
paint brush was inaugurated last
year by the Class of '22, and bethe upper classes saw fit
to condone this`deed once it seems
to have established a precedent to
which each succeeding Freshman
Class must adhere.
If drastic measures are not
taken shortly, in the course of
five years there will be no scenery
left at Hopkins—it will be a mass
of numerals and scores of longsince forgotten inter-class contests.
If we will glance back in our
memories to last year and stroll
down the walk to the Barn, we

may recall a large red and white
banner flying gracefully from the
center window of the Student Activities Building. This banner is
better known as a service flag, on
which were the figures 760, and
many black stars, to which were
added from time to time more
stars, and finally one gold one,
representing the number of Hopkins men in the service of their
country,
This service flag was presented
to the University by thefOmicron
Delta Kappa Society in commemoration of the gallant sons of
Johns Hopkins who were risking
their lives for freedom and democracy. Considerable ceremony accompanied this presentation, and
Hopkins men were proud to point
to it as they showed their friends
around the campus.
Now, we find it hanging in the
Civil Engineering Lecture Hall,
gathering dust, and rapidly deteriorating. It is placed over the hole
for the motion-picture projector,
and is pinned aside at any time a
lecturer wishes to illustrate his
talk. Such usage is hardly worthy
a flag to which so much veneration
should be attached.
We suggest that it be put in
some place where it can best withstand the ravages of time, attended by suitable ceremony on the
part of the University. If it does
not mean anything to us now, it
will in years to come be looked
upon with reverance and pride,
and hence should be protected to
the best of our ability.
